abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Global Environmental
            Facility (GEF) Manila Third Sewerage Project (MTSP) for
            Philippines were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was substantial,
            Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the results framework should have been
            based upon data available from existing monitoring systems,
            rather than on assumed improvements to be developed during
            the lifetime of the project and the global environmental
            objective (GEO) indicators should have been within the scope
            and timeframe of the project. Assessments of mandates,
            functions, and processes, in national and local agencies - a
            fit for partnering assessment - should have been be
            completed during the design of the project and actions to
            build institutional capacity to partner effectively
            identified. Financial incentives and increased awareness can
            bring results; for example the feedback from Laguna lake
            development authority (LLDA) that expanding the pollutants
            covered under the environmental user fee (through Laguna de
            bay institutional strengthening and community participation
            (LISCOP)) and the awareness raising (through GEF MTSP) has
            led to reduction of pollution.
